questions.text: Investigation of choice for Unilateral stress fracture is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRI Option: B. MRI has superior anatomical depiction and tissue specificity. It detects marrow edema and helps in diagnosing it.

Highyeild:

For localized problems MRI has superseded bone scintigraphy as it yields much greater specificity due to its superior anatomical depiction and tissue specificity. Investigation of choice for stress fracture Overall - MRI Unilateral – MRI Bilateral – Bone scan INVESTIGATIONS IN ORTHOPEDICS X-Ray: "Rule of 2" ↪2 views ↪2 joints ↪2 sides ↪2 occasions (2 weeks: Scaphoid #) MRI 10C for soft tissues IOC for stress # (Single site / unilateral) 10C for occult # associated with Avascular Necrosis ↪Scaphoid / Neck of femur / Talus. CT scan → Bone # calcaneum → 3D CT Scan Calcifications

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. CT scans not as useful as MRI in diagnosing unilateral stress fractures Option: C. Investigation of choice in bilateral or multiple stress fractures. Option: D. Difficult to diagnose unilateral stress fractures with x-rays alone and hence not the Investigation of choice.

questions.text: The most common cause for pathological fracture is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Osteoporosis Option: A. Osteoporosis has the highest incidence and is the most common cause of pathological fracture.

Highyeild:

Pathological fractures are due to some under lying cause or diseases. The causes can be a. Local diseases b. General diseases Infections (Osteomyelitis) Congenital disorders like osteogenesis imperfecta Bone tumors (Benign or malignant) Metabolic: Rickets, Osteomalacia, Osteoporosis etc. Disseminated diseases like multiple myeloma Diffuse involvement of bone like in Paget's diseases Features of pathological fracture Bones usually gets fractured spontaneously or after trivial injury like in osteoporosis Associated symptoms can be cough, weight loss, lump or swelling or hematuria. These are usually associated with malignant deposits (secondaries) Repeated fractures in a child may favor a diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta. Examination Infective condition may have associated infected sinus swelling or deformity. Osteoporotic patients may have pain over common sites like pubic rami or neck of femur. These may also have loss of height due to involvement of vertebra. Malignancy or secondary deposits may have associated enlargement of lymph nodes. There may be wasting of muscles palpable mass in abdomen. In these patients the rectal and surgical examination must be done. There may be associated anemia, loss weight, appetite in these patients Investigation Blood evaluation: CBC, ESR, S.Ca, S. Ph, S. alkaline phosphatase (Protein electrophoresis) Urine: May show presence of bence jones proteins X-Ray: These are the first line investigation in case of fractures. The X-Ray may show compression of vertebra like in osteoporosis, cystic lesion like in UBC (fallen fragment sign) or sclerosis around the fracture suggestive of pseudo fractures as seen in osteomalacia. If malignancy is suspected X ray of chest should always be done. MRI or CT can be done depending on the suspected pathology Biopsy may be needed in few cases to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment It depends on the cause suspected and the underlying pathological condition The different modalities that may be used to stabilize the fracture can be conservative by slab or cast application or internal fixation in long bone or prosthetic replacement like in fracture related to fracture neck of femur.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Primary malignancy can cause pathological fractures but Osteoporosis has the highest incidence Option: C. Metastasis can cause pathological fractures but Osteoporosis has the highest incidence. Option :D. Osteomalacia can cause pathological fractures but Osteoporosis has the highest incidence.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male while playing cricket, threw the ball and immediately got severe pain around his shoulder and was unable to use it further. His friends noticed an abnormal bony prominence around the anterior aspect of the shoulder. Which is the most likely type of given dislocation is most commonly expected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sub coracoid Sub coracoid - The head lies below the coracoid process. A most common type of dislocation , so the correct answer is option B.

Highyeild:

DISLOCATION OF SHOULDER JOINT: Classification: Dislocations of the shoulder may be of the following types: a) Anterior dislocation: In this injury, the head of the humerus comes out of the glenoid cavity and lies anteriorly. It may be further classified into three subtypes depending on the position of the dislocated head (Fig-13.4). Preglenoid: The head lies in front of the glenoid. • Subcoracoid: The head lies below the coracoid process. Most common type of dislocation. Subclavicular: The head lies below the clavicle. Posterior dislocation: In this injury, the head of the humerus comes to lie posteriorly, behind the glenoid. Luxatio erecta (inferior dislocation): This is a rare type, where the head comes to lie in the subglenoid position.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Preglenoid - The head lies in front of the glenoid. Option: C. Intrathoracic -head lies within the thoracic cavity. Option: D. Infraclavicular- The head lies below the clavicle.

questions.text: What type of fracture healing is demonstrated in the radiograph below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Secondary Bone healing Option B. - Secondary Bone healing- Secondary fracture healing occurs in fractures where fracture hematoma is not disturbed, as in cases treated non-operatively. There is healing , with callus formation, and can be evaluated on X-rays. It also occurs in fractures operated without disturbing the fracture hematoma, as in fractures fixed with relative stability (e.g. comminuted fractures and intramedullary nailing).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Primary Bone healing - Primary fracture healing occurs where fracture hematoma has been disturbed, as in fractures treated operatively. This is a case of closed reduction where secondary healing occurs. Option C. - Bone Remodelling- Bone remodeling (or bone metabolism) is a lifelong process where mature bone tissue is removed from the skeleton (a process called bone resorption) and new bone tissue is formed Option D. - None of the above- Not applicable

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who is on epileptics sustained a fall in the bathroom. You order radiographs and diagnose her with a fractured shaft of radius in her right forearm. What is the pathognomonic sign of fresh fracture?

Crepitus Crepitus- a pathognomonic sign of fresh fracture. The pathognomonic sign of a traumatic fracture is crepitus at the fracture site.
